comments.body: If state is `get` and value isn't provided I think [line 518 ](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/32297/files#diff-ee65e55980e15661bf789266142f496cR518) will fail now (because value_in will be None rather than an empty list). Perhaps [line 461 ](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/32297/files#diff-ee65e55980e15661bf789266142f496cL461) could be `value_in = module.params.get('value') or []`?
ahh, you are right. Sorry about that. Thanks for reviewing.

comments.body: I don't understand what this changes, as line 621 just sorts the resource records again whether or not `need_to_sort_records` is true or not.

This changes the `rset` object itself; it's needed because the comparison is done in line 621 between `rset` and `wanted_rset`. All the other lines (i.e. putting stuff into `record`) is done only for `state == 'get'` if I understand it correctly, and not used anywhere else (in particular, not for comparison).

I kept the sorting in line 621 because that used to be done for all record types (but as I said, it is only used for `state == 'get'`); I could have only sorted again if it wasn't sorted here already, but I thought that would make it unnecessary complex.
Right, I nearly wrote another comment about how I still don't understand but I got there while writing it :)

comments.body:
I think this could be more concise as 

```
if type_in == 'CAA':
    wanted_rset.resource_records.sort()
```

That way we'd just be using the in-place sort rather than creating new vars.
But `unsorted_records` would no longer be the original copy, since it will be sorted as well.
